items.title: Ukraine war live: ‘Russia must end this war,’ Zelenskyy says as he arrives in Washington for Trump talks
items.standfirst: Ukrainian president hopes ‘joint strength with America, with our European friends, will force Russia into a real peace’ as he joins leaders from Europe in Washington for crucial summit with Donald TrumpTrump rules out Ukraine reclaiming Crimea or joining Nato as European leaders gather in WashingtonA Russian drone attack on a five-storey apartment block in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv early Monday killed five people and wounded more than a dozen others, Ukrainian authorities said.The attack, which took place just before dawn, reduced part of the building to rubble and sparked fires on at least three floors, the region’s governor Oleg Synegubov said on Telegram. items.title: Live: Zelensky lands in US for Ukraine peace talks as Trump rules out 'getting back' Crimea
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and a number of European leaders arrived in Washington, DC on Sunday night to meet with US President Donald Trump the following day for talks aimed at ending the war with Ukraine. Trump said reclaiming Crimea or entering NATO were off the table for Kyiv, claiming that Zelensky could end the conflict "almost immediately" if he wanted to. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and a number of European leaders arrived in Washington, DC on Sunday night to meet with US President Donald Trump the following day for talks aimed at ending the war with Ukraine. Trump said reclaiming Crimea or entering NATO were off the table for Kyiv, claiming that Zelensky could end the conflict "almost immediately" if he wanted to. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: Trump rules out Ukraine reclaiming Crimea or joining Nato as European leaders gather in Washington
items.standfirst: US president’s comments may prove a setback for Volodymyr Zelenskyy as he flies to US for crucial Oval Office meeting in wake of Alaska summitDonald Trump has put pressure on Volodymyr Zelenskyy ahead of Monday’s talks in Washington with European leaders, saying the Ukrainian president could end the war “almost immediately” if he wanted to. The US president also ruled out allowing Ukraine to join Nato or retake Russian-occupied Crimea as part of negotiations with Moscow.Trump posted the remarks on his Truth Social platform on Sunday night, hours before he was due to meet European leaders including Keir Starmer, Emmanuel Macron, Friedrich Merz, and Zelenskyy at the Oval Office in a bid to counter a reportedly US-backed plan that would see Ukraine give up territory. Continue reading...
items.content: US president’s comments may prove a setback for Volodymyr Zelenskyy as he flies to US for crucial Oval Office meeting in wake of Alaska summitDonald Trump has put pressure on Volodymyr Zelenskyy ahead of Monday’s talks in Washington with European leaders, saying the Ukrainian president could end the war “almost immediately” if he wanted to. The US president also ruled out allowing Ukraine to join Nato or retake Russian-occupied Crimea as part of negotiations with Moscow.Trump posted the remarks on his Truth Social platform on Sunday night, hours before he was due to meet European leaders including Keir Starmer, Emmanuel Macron, Friedrich Merz, and Zelenskyy at the Oval Office in a bid to counter a reportedly US-backed plan that would see Ukraine give up territory. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelenskyy says territorial swaps not possible under Ukrainian constitution ahead of White House meeting – live
items.standfirst: Steve Witkoff says Russian president agreed to allow US and European allies to offer Ukraine security guarantee and also unspecified concessions on five Ukrainian regionsGermany’s chancellor, Friedrich Merz, will also be travelling to Washington tomorrow for the Trump-Zelenskyy talks, according to the federal government.The chancellor’s spokesperson has been quoted by BBC News as having said:The trip will serve as an exchange of information with US President Donald Trump following his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska.Chancellor Merz will discuss the status of peace efforts with the heads of state and government and underscore Germany’s interest in a swift peace agreement in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: NATO-like protection for Ukraine in focus as Zelensky, European leaders head for Trump meeting
items.standfirst: European and NATO leaders are joining Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Washington on Monday to present a united front in talks with President Donald Trump. US special envoy Steve Witkoff on Sunday said Russia is open to the idea of the US and its European allies offering Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO’s collective defence mandate.
items.content: European and NATO leaders are joining Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Washington on Monday to present a united front in talks with President Donald Trump. US special envoy Steve Witkoff on Sunday said Russia is open to the idea of the US and its European allies offering Ukraine a security guarantee resembling NATO’s collective defence mandate.

items.title: After meeting Putin, Trump changes his position on the need for a ceasefire
items.standfirst: When President Trump was flying to Alaska to meet Vladimir Putin, he said the goal was a ceasefire. But after they talked, Trump aligned himself with Putin and downplayed the need for a truce.
items.content: When President Trump was flying to Alaska to meet Vladimir Putin, he said the goal was a ceasefire. But after they talked, Trump aligned himself with Putin and downplayed the need for a truce. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

items.title: Trump drops ceasefire demand, echoing Putin’s position and jittering Ukraine
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.
items.content: US President Donald Trump reversed course after his meeting in Alaska with Russia’s Vladimir Putin by abandoning his demand for a ceasefire and adopting a Kremlin position calling for a full peace deal to end the Ukraine war.

items.content: Ukraine and its allies were scrambling Sunday to respond to President Donald Trump's apparent shift toward Vladimir Putin's hardline position after their summit in Alaska.

items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin addressed senior officials in the Kremlin on the outcome of talks with President Donald Trump in Alaska.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Zelenskyy arrived in Washington for meetings with US and European leaders.
• He hopes for joint strength to force Russia into a real peace agreement.
• A Russian drone attack in Kharkiv killed five and injured over a dozen.
• European markets are expected to open higher ahead of the talks.
• Trump ruled out Ukraine reclaiming Crimea or joining NATO.

clusters.title: Air Canada strike: Cabin crew defy return to work order
clusters.neutral_headline: Air Canada flight attendants continue strike despite order
bullet_summary: Air Canada said on Sunday it had suspended plans to restart operations after a union representing flight attendants said it would continue to strike
The union representing Air Canada's striking flight attendants on Sunday said it will remain on strike and spurn a government return-to-work order that they called unconstitutional
Air Canada said Sunday it has suspended its plan to resume limited flights after the union representing its flight attendants told members to defy a federal order to return to work

The strike, which began on Saturday morning, stranded more than 100,000 travelers around the world during…

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants to continue strike despite government order
items.standfirst: Workers at Canada's flagship carrier defy back-to-work order as they stage first strike in 40 years.
items.content: Workers at Canada's flagship carrier defy back-to-work order as they stage first strike in 40 years.

items.title: Air Canada suspends restart plans after union defies return to work order
items.standfirst: Air Canada will resume flights Monday evening, claiming the union illegally directed flight attendants to defy a return-to-work order.
items.content: Air Canada will resume flights Monday evening, claiming the union illegally directed flight attendants to defy a return-to-work order.(Image credit: Graham Hughes)

items.title: Air Canada delays return to flights after union defies government order
items.standfirst: Canada's jobs minister intervened in the dispute in a bid to preserve "stability and supply chains".
items.content: Canada's jobs minister intervened in the dispute in a bid to preserve "stability and supply chains".

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants defy back-to-work order, continue strike
items.standfirst: The union representing Air Canada's striking flight attendants on Sunday said it will remain on strike and spurn a government return-to-work order that they called unconstitutional. The strike has stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer travel season.
items.content: The union representing Air Canada's striking flight attendants on Sunday said it will remain on strike and spurn a government return-to-work order that they called unconstitutional. The strike has stranded more than 100,000 passengers across the world during the peak summer travel season.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants to defy back-to-work order and remain on strike
items.standfirst: Union to challenge order issued less than 12 hours after start of action that has left more than 100,000 travellers strandedAir Canada’s flight attendants plan to remain on strike, their union has said, defying government efforts to force them back to work and into binding arbitration over a dispute that has left more than 100,000 travellers stranded around the world during the peak summer travel season.About 10,000 flight attendants who work for Canada’s largest airline walked out on the job early on Saturday amid a bitter dispute over what the union has described as “poverty wages” and unpaid labour. Continue reading...
items.content: Union to challenge order issued less than 12 hours after start of action that has left more than 100,000 travellers strandedAir Canada’s flight attendants plan to remain on strike, their union has said, defying government efforts to force them back to work and into binding arbitration over a dispute that has left more than 100,000 travellers stranded around the world during the peak summer travel season.About 10,000 flight attendants who work for Canada’s largest airline walked out on the job early on Saturday amid a bitter dispute over what the union has described as “poverty wages” and unpaid labour. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada halts flight restart after union defies back-to-work order
items.standfirst: Air Canada said Sunday it has suspended its plan to resume limited flights after the union representing its flight attendants told members to defy a federal order to return to work.
items.content: Air Canada said Sunday it has suspended its plan to resume limited flights after the union representing its flight attendants told members to defy a federal order to return to work.

items.title: Air Canada to resume flights after government ends flight attendant strike
items.standfirst: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.
items.content: Canada’s labour board has ordered Air Canada to resume operations after a nationwide flight attendant strike grounded over 700 flights. The directive, issued following a request from Jobs Minister Patty Hajdu, marks the end of the airline’s first flight attendant walkout since 1985.

items.title: Canadian government orders arbitration to resolve Air Canada flight attendants' strike
items.standfirst: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.
items.content: Air Canada suspended all operations Saturday morning after more than 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job over pay and scheduling disputes, prompting the Canadian government to step in.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Air Canada flight attendants defied a government return-to-work order.
• The strike has stranded over 100,000 passengers worldwide.
• The union is challenging the order, calling it unconstitutional.
• Air Canada delayed plans to resume services due to the strike.
• Canada's jobs minister intervened to preserve stability and supply chains.

clusters.title: Bolivia's presidential vote goes to runoff between centrist and right-wing candidates
clusters.neutral_headline: Bolivia to hold runoff election after no outright winner
bullet_summary: Rodrigo Paz, drew more votes than the right-wing front-runners, although not enough to secure an outright victory, early results showed
Reported by NPR News, Al Jazeera, Guardian World and others

items.title: Bolivia's presidential vote goes to runoff between centrist and right-wing candidates
items.standfirst: A dark horse centrist, Sen. Rodrigo Paz, drew more votes than the right-wing front-runners, although not enough to secure an outright victory, early results showed.
items.content: A dark horse centrist, Sen. Rodrigo Paz, drew more votes than the right-wing front-runners, although not enough to secure an outright victory, early results showed.(Image credit: Freddy Barragan, Arnulfo Franco)

items.title: Bolivia to hold presidential run-off between centrist and right-winger
items.standfirst: Early results show centrist Rodrigo Paz in the lead, with 32.8 percent of the vote.
items.content: Early results show centrist Rodrigo Paz in the lead, with 32.8 percent of the vote.

items.title: Bolivia presidential election: preliminary results put two rightwing candidates in run-off vote
items.standfirst: First-round result marks the end of nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo as economic crisis grips the countryBolivia’s presidential election will go to a run-off for the first time, with two rightwing candidates competing for the presidency – marking the end of nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The candidate with the most votes, however, turned out to be a surprise: centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 57, who had started the campaign with just 3% support in opinion polls. Continue reading...
items.content: First-round result marks the end of nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo as economic crisis grips the countryBolivia’s presidential election will go to a run-off for the first time, with two rightwing candidates competing for the presidency – marking the end of nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The candidate with the most votes, however, turned out to be a surprise: centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 57, who had started the campaign with just 3% support in opinion polls. Continue reading...

items.title: Bolivia Heads to First-Ever Presidential Runoff as Centrist Leads
items.standfirst: Senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira leads the presidential vote with 32.8%, forcing the nation's first-ever runoff election against its right-wing rival.
items.content: Senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira leads the presidential vote with 32.8%, forcing the nation's first-ever runoff election against its right-wing rival.

items.title: Bolivia heads for first-ever runoff election
items.standfirst: Bolivia heads for a runoff election after no candidate managed to secure enough votes for an outright win, according to early poll results.Senator Rodrigo Paz, a moderate who aims to ease the austerit...
items.content: Bolivia heads for a runoff election after no candidate managed to secure enough votes for an outright win, according to early poll results.Senator Rodrigo Paz, a moderate who aims to ease the austerit...

items.title: Bolivia's presidential vote heads to run-off between centre-right and right-wing candidates
items.standfirst: Centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz and right-wing former president Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga are headed to the second round of Bolivia's presidential elections following a first round of voting Sunday that brought an end to more than two decades of left-wing rule in the country.
items.content: Centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz and right-wing former president Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga are headed to the second round of Bolivia's presidential elections following a first round of voting Sunday that brought an end to more than two decades of left-wing rule in the country.

items.title: Bolivians go to polls in election that could end 20 years of leftist rule
items.standfirst: Rightwing candidates lead polling ahead of fragmented left amid country’s worst economic crisis in four decadesBolivians are going to the polls in an election that could mark a shift to the right and the end of nearly 20 years of rule by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The party, which came to power with the first election of Evo Morales in 2005, risks losing its legal status if it fails to reach 3% of the vote – a threshold it has not hit in polls. Continue reading...
items.content: Rightwing candidates lead polling ahead of fragmented left amid country’s worst economic crisis in four decadesBolivians are going to the polls in an election that could mark a shift to the right and the end of nearly 20 years of rule by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The party, which came to power with the first election of Evo Morales in 2005, risks losing its legal status if it fails to reach 3% of the vote – a threshold it has not hit in polls. Continue reading...

items.title: Polls close in Bolivia as 20 years of leftist rule expected to end
items.standfirst: Right-wing candidates are the frontrunners in elections marked by economic crisis and division in the socialist ranks.
items.content: Right-wing candidates are the frontrunners in elections marked by economic crisis and division in the socialist ranks.

items.title: Bolivians head to the polls in elections marked by economic crisis
items.standfirst: Bolivians head to the polls Sunday (August 17) for elections marked by a deep economic crisis that has seen the left implode and the right eyeing its first shot at power in 20 years.
items.content: Bolivians head to the polls Sunday (August 17) for elections marked by a deep economic crisis that has seen the left implode and the right eyeing its first shot at power in 20 years.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Bolivia will hold its first-ever presidential runoff election.
• Centrist Senator Rodrigo Paz leads with 32.8% of the vote.
• The election marks the end of nearly 20 years of leftist rule.
• Two right-wing candidates will compete in the runoff.
• Early results showed a surprise lead for the centrist candidate.

items.content: Protesters in Israel escalated their ongoing campaign on Sunday to secure the release of hostages held in Gaza.

items.title: Thousands of Israelis protest war in Gaza, call for end to fighting
items.standfirst: Thousands of Israeli protesters on Sunday demanded a deal to secure the release of hostages still held by Hamas in one of the biggest demonstrations since the war in Gaza began. Debora Patta reports.
items.content: Thousands of Israeli protesters on Sunday demanded a deal to secure the release of hostages still held by Hamas in one of the biggest demonstrations since the war in Gaza began. Debora Patta reports.

items.title: Tens of thousands of protesters gather in Tel Aviv to demand end to Gaza war
items.standfirst: One of largest rallies in Israel since start of conflict follows general strike to press government to stop military actionTens of thousands of demonstrators have gathered in Tel Aviv to call for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.The rally on Sunday evening was the culmination of a day of nationwide protests and a general strike to pressure the government to halt the military campaign. “Bring them all home! Stop the war!” shouted the vast crowd, which had converged on the so-called Hostage Square in Tel Aviv plaza – a focal point for protesters throughout the war. Continue reading...
items.content: One of largest rallies in Israel since start of conflict follows general strike to press government to stop military actionTens of thousands of demonstrators have gathered in Tel Aviv to call for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.The rally on Sunday evening was the culmination of a day of nationwide protests and a general strike to pressure the government to halt the military campaign. “Bring them all home! Stop the war!” shouted the vast crowd, which had converged on the so-called Hostage Square in Tel Aviv plaza – a focal point for protesters throughout the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Huge crowds gather in Israel calling for hostage deal and end to Gaza war
items.standfirst: Large crowds fill 'Hostages Square' in Tel Aviv to call for fighting to cease and the release of all remaining hostages by Hamas.
items.content: Large crowds fill 'Hostages Square' in Tel Aviv to call for fighting to cease and the release of all remaining hostages by Hamas.

items.title: Mass rallies erupt across Israel as protesters demand end to Gaza war, hostage deal
items.standfirst: Mass protests erupted across Israel Sunday as tens of thousands called for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.
items.content: Mass protests erupted across Israel Sunday as tens of thousands called for an end to the war in Gaza and the release of hostages, one of the largest demonstrations in Israel since the start of the fighting in October 2023.

items.title: Israeli plan to displace 1 million Palestinians spreads fear in Gaza
items.standfirst: Population devastated by repeated displacement, hunger and lack of medical supplies braces for further humanitarian disaster Palestinians were gripped by fear and anxiety on Sunday after the Israeli military said it was preparing for the forcible displacement of 1 million people from Gaza City.The announcement came days after Israel said it intended to launch a new offensive to seize control of the territory’s largest urban centre, in a plan that raised international alarm, and ahead of the IDF’s latest attacks in the Palestinian territory which Gaza’s health officials said had killed at least 40 people on Saturday including a baby in a tent and people seeking aid. Continue reading...
items.content: Population devastated by repeated displacement, hunger and lack of medical supplies braces for further humanitarian disaster Palestinians were gripped by fear and anxiety on Sunday after the Israeli military said it was preparing for the forcible displacement of 1 million people from Gaza City.The announcement came days after Israel said it intended to launch a new offensive to seize control of the territory’s largest urban centre, in a plan that raised international alarm, and ahead of the IDF’s latest attacks in the Palestinian territory which Gaza’s health officials said had killed at least 40 people on Saturday including a baby in a tent and people seeking aid. Continue reading...

items.title: Protesters go on strike in Israel demanding ceasefire
items.standfirst: Protestors in Israel demanding their government make a deal to secure the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza escalated their campaign on Sunday, (August 16) staging a strike. Meanwhile, Israel said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more. "It may be part of a psychological warfare operation to try and persuade Gazans to leave their homes or whatever spaces they were in, in central Gaza", she said.
items.content: Protestors in Israel demanding their government make a deal to secure the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza escalated their campaign on Sunday, (August 16) staging a strike. Meanwhile, Israel said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more. "It may be part of a psychological warfare operation to try and persuade Gazans to leave their homes or whatever spaces they were in, in central Gaza", she said.

items.title: Israeli military prepares to move Palestinians to southern Gaza
items.standfirst: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas
items.content: International condemnation and pressure from allies have done nothing to stop Israel's plan to displace the people of northern Gaza. Israel on Saturday (August 16) said it is preparing to move Palestinians from combat zones to southern Gaza as plans move ahead for a military offensive in some of the territory's most populated areas

items.title: Nationwide protests over Gaza war, hostage deal sweep Israel
items.standfirst: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.
items.content: Demonstrators rallied across Israel on Sunday (August 17), demanding an end to the war in Gaza and a deal to free the remaining hostages, as the military readies a new offensive. The protests come amid rising domestic pressure and international concern over the humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian territory. Protest organisers and the main campaign group representing the families of hostages also called for a general strike.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Thousands of Israelis protested for a ceasefire and hostage release.
• Demonstrations were among the largest since the war began.
• Protesters gathered in Tel Aviv's "Hostage Square."
• A general strike was held to pressure the government.
• Protesters demanded an end to the war in Gaza.

items.standfirst: Victims ranged from ages 27 to 61 after multiple gunmen opened fire after what police suspect was gang violenceThree people were killed and eight others wounded when multiple gunmen opened fire inside a crowded Brooklyn hookah lounge and restaurant early on Sunday morning, according to authorities.Police officers responded to reports of a shooting inside the Taste of the City lounge in Crown Heights just before 3.30am, New York police department (NYPD) commissioner, Jessica Tisch, said at a press briefing later on Sunday. items.title: Watchdog condemned for clearing Grant Shapps to join defence startup
items.standfirst: Former defence secretary allowed to take role as chair of Cambridge Aerospace, as long as he avoids defence mattersThe parliamentary standards body has been criticised for clearing Grant Shapps, a former Conservative defence secretary, to join a defence startup as long as he promises not to work on defence matters.In a ruling that drew scorn from political ethics experts, the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments (Acoba), which monitors and advises on the revolving door between Westminster and the business sector, gave Shapps the green light to become the chair of Cambridge Aerospace. Continue reading...
items.content: Former defence secretary allowed to take role as chair of Cambridge Aerospace, as long as he avoids defence mattersThe parliamentary standards body has been criticised for clearing Grant Shapps, a former Conservative defence secretary, to join a defence startup as long as he promises not to work on defence matters.In a ruling that drew scorn from political ethics experts, the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments (Acoba), which monitors and advises on the revolving door between Westminster and the business sector, gave Shapps the green light to become the chair of Cambridge Aerospace. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Grant Shapps was cleared to join a defense startup.
• He must avoid defense matters in his new role.
• The parliamentary standards body was criticized.
• Shapps is the former Conservative defense secretary.
• He will chair Cambridge Aerospace.
